container-title: During the 400s B.C., training in rhetoric increased rapidly, especially in ATHENS. This training developed into an organized body of teaching material and became the foundation of education in western Europe well into the Middle Ages

title: * tribute payment made to a dominant power PERSIAN EMPIRE. From about 454 B.C., Ephesus paid tribute* to Athens, but or local government the city revolted and joined SPARTA in the PELOPONNESIAN WAR against the Athenians

container-title: and Lucius Tarquinius Superbus, or Tarquin the Proud (534-510 B.C.), both of whom were also Etruscan. By the time the Romans overthrew the monarchy in 510 B.C
note: to establish a republic of their own, Rome—built in the image of the Etruscan city-states—had become the foremost city in Latium.
title: self, beginning in the late 600s B.C. From the time of its legendary founding in 753 B.C., Rome was a rural and agricultural village of huts, as opposed to the urban society in Etruria. In 616 B.C., the first of three Etruscanborn kings assumed power in Rome. Beginning with the reign of Lucius Tarquinius Priscus (616-579 B.C.), Rome was transformed from a village on the banks of the Tiber River into a full-fledged city-state. Brick buildings replaced mud huts; paved roads replaced dirt tracks; sewers and other public works were built; and the first TEMPLES were erected. This process continued under the next two Roman kings, Servius Tullius (578-535 B.C
Romans burned and destroyed CARTHAGE in 146 B.C., and he also helped the

container-title: In the first century A.D., the city of Rome had about a million inhabitants
note: and the total population of the Roman empire is estimated to have been more than 50 million people. (See also Census, Roman; Greece, History of; Rome, History of.
title: in the 400s B.C. This rose to about 300,000 two centuries later. As the Roman empire expanded, and certain conquered peoples received Roman CITIZENSHIP, the population increased accordingly. In 70 B.C., after citizen-See map in Migrations, Late Roman ship was granted to all people of Italy south of the Po River, the figure (vol.3). reached 900,000. A census of the empire conducted by the emperor AUGUSTUS in 28 B.C. put the figure at about 4 million citizens
south and east of the Iberian Peninsula, the landmass on which Spain is located. The PHOENICIANS, a people from the eastern Mediterranean, established a settlement in southern Spain around 1100 B.C

note: which they divided into two provinces* in 197 B.C. War between the Romans and native groups of people continued, however, ending in 133 B.C. Because the mountainous northern and northwestern regions were difficult to conquer, Rome controlled only about half of the Iberian Peninsula. Although the Roman generals POMPEY
title: * city-state independent state consisting of a The Greeks first settled Spain in the 600s B.C., when the city-state* of city and its surrounding territory Phocaea in ASIA MINOR founded colonies on the eastern coast of the peninsula. During the early 200s B.C., the North African city of CARTHAGE conquered southern Spain in its attempt to control the western MEDITERRANEAN SEA. During the PUNIC WARS against Rome, the Carthaginians exploited Spanish natural resources and manpower. After the First Punic War ended in 241 B.C., Carthage extended its control in Spain by founding the city of Carthago Nova on Spain's eastern coast. Rome drove the Carthaginians from Spain during the Second Punic War in the late 200s B.C. The Romans controlled the eastern and south-* province overseas area controlled by Rome eastern coastal regions of Spain

container-title: HADRIAN, and Marcus AURELIUS were of Spanish ancestry. Spain also produced some of the most important Latin writers of the first century A.D., such as the statesman SENECA, the educator QUINTILIAN, and the poet MARTIAL. Roman control of Spain ended with the invasion of the VISIGOTHS in the A.D. 400s
note: See also Colonies, Greek; Colonies, Roman; Migrations, Late Roman.
title: * Roman Republic Rome during the period and Julius CAESAR led troops into Spain during the late Roman Republic*, from 509 B.C. to 3 1 B.C., when popular Rome did not conquer the rest of the peninsula until the reign of AUGUSTUS, assemblies annually elected their governmental the first Roman emperor. officials Rome established many colonies throughout the Spanish provinces. The Romans built a network of ROADS, BRIDGES, and AQUEDUCTS and developed numerous gold and silver mines. Spain provided the Roman empire with important agricultural products, such as WINE and olive oil. As early as the first century B.C., some senators were from Spain, and the emperors TRAJAN

container-title: 474 B.C. Gelon's brother Hieron defeated the ETRUSCANS in a naval battle off the coast of Italy. With these victories, Syracuse became a leading power in the Mediterranean region
title: settlers from CORINTH in the 700s B.C. The 400s B.C. marked the high point of the city's power. At the Battle of Himera in 480 B.C., Syracuse, * tyrant absolute ruler led by the tyrant* Gelon, defeated CARTHAGE, a city in northern Africa

note: During the First Punic War between Rome and Carthage, which lasted from 264 B.C. to 241 B.C., Syracuse allied itself with Rome. During the Second Punic War, however, the ruler of Syracuse sided with Carthage, a decision
title: The tyrannies of Syracuse eventually gave way to a democracy in the 460s B.C. During the PELOPONNESIAN WAR between Athens and Sparta in the late 400s B.C., the Athenians attacked Syracuse. The Syracusans resisted and See map in Rome, History of

were victorious. After two subsequent invasions of Sicily by Carthage, the Syracusan tyrant Dionysius I took control of the city. He waged four wars against Charthage and extended the city's power over most of Sicily and much of southern Italy. Dionysius also fortified the city with a wall that ran 17 miles along its border

container-title: Although the ruling classes in Hellenistic* culture of the Mediterranean world during the Syria spoke Greek, most of the people of Syria continued to speak Aramaic
note: three centuries after Alexander the Great, who an ancient language of the Middle East. (See also Provinces, Roman; Seleudied in 323 B.C. cid Dynasty; Trade, Roman.
title: * province overseas area controlled by Rome made it a province* of the Roman empire. The Roman emperor SEPTIMIUS SEVERUS divided Syria into two provinces in the late A.D. 100s. Syria was mainly a rural province, although it did contain several important cities, including ANTIOCH, tyre, and Damascus. The province was a valuable agricultural region, producing WINE, olives, nuts, dates, wool, linen, See map in Provinces

and purple dyes. Syrian craftspeople produced blown glass and other valuable items. Trade caravans traveling between the Mediterranean coast and Mesopotamia and Arabia stopped at several important trade centers in the province. Syria was also important for other reasons. The Roman army recruited many of its soldiers from among the people of Syria, and the land separated the rest of the Roman empire from the Parthians and the Sassa-* Hellenistic referring to the Greek-influenced nians, peoples of western Asia

container-title: Archaeological evidence shows that the city was looted, burned, and abandoned sometime in the 1200s B.C. By the 500s B.C
note: Thebes had regained its power, and it became leader of the
title: hero in mythology, a person of great strength the legendary house of OEDIPUS, immortalized by the Greek playwrights or ability often descended from a god AESCHYLUS
Thebes was a strong, prosperous city that rivaled MYCENAE for the leadership of early Greece

note: Under Roman rule, the city revolted twice and suf-* barbarian referring to people from outside fered more destruction. During the later Roman Empire, barbarian* tribes the cultures of Greece and Rome, who were from the north captured the city twice. (See also Greece, History of; Myths, viewed as uncivilized Greek; Polis.
title: * confederacy group of states joined together Boeotian League, a confederacy* of cities and towns in central Greece. for a purpose In about 519 B.C., hostility arose between Thebes and ATHENS over control of Boeotia. During the PERSIAN WARS, the people of Thebes sided with Persia against Athens. When the Persians were defeated, Thebes lost its leadership of the Boeotian League. After an Athenian victory over Thebes in 457 B.C., the government of the city was changed from an OLIGARCHY, or rule by a few, to a See map in Sparta

The oligarchy was restored when Thebes won a victory over Athens in 447 B.C. During the PELOPONNESIAN WAR, Thebes sided with SPARTA against Athens. Later, however, it fought against Sparta and eventually drove the Spartans from central Greece. King PHILIP II of MACEDONIA captured Thebes in 338 B.C. When Thebes revolted against Philip's son ALEXANDER THE GREAT a few years later, the Macedonians destroyed the city. Although it was rebuilt, Thebes never regained its former greatness

note: 386 he signed a treaty with Persia, agreeing to divide the long-disputed kingdom of Armenia between the two empires. Theodosius also sought to strengthen the empire by securing its faith. In
title: THEODOSIUS eral crises facing the late Roman Empire. His policies toward the barbarian Goths helped reduce the threat of invasion. Agreements with the PERSIAN EMPIRE resolved long-standing disputes that threatened staca.A.D. 346-395 bility in the east. Theodosius's religious policies helped strengthen the rela-ROMAN EMPEROR tionship between the Christian church and the state. Born in northwestern SPAIN, Flavius Theodosius was the son of a prominent Roman general

379 the emperor Gratian declared Theodosius the ruler of the Eastern Roman Empire and enlisted his help in fighting the Goths. Unable to defeat the Goths in battle, Theodosius signed a treaty with them in A.D. 382, allowing them to settle within the empire in return for their military assistance. Soon after easing the Gothic threat, Theodosius worked to strengthen the borders of the empire by securing its eastern frontiers

note: or god been formulated in A.D. 325. He later banned pagan cults* and rituals, allowed

title: Other ancient battles were fought at Thermopylae as well. In 279 B.C. a Greek army failed to defend the pass from invading CELTS. In 191 B.C. Roman soldiers defeated Syrian troops who attempted to invade Greece through Thermopylae, and in A.D. 395 Romans guarding the pass were defeated by invading VISIGOTHS

Macedonian rulers controlled Thrace until the Romans conquered the region in the mid-100s B.C

title: 79. Although he ruled for only two •.'.«Av- years, his reign was a happy one for the Roman people. Titus earned their respect and loyalty through his capable administration and his concern A.D

note: had been started by his father. During Titus's reign, the empire suffered three great disasters: the eruption of Mt. VESUVIUS in A.D. 79 and a great fire and plague in Rome the following year. Titus responded to these disasters by offering government relief to those who had suffered. When Titus died in A.D. 81, the Romans truly mourned him. The Roman biographer SUETONIUS called Titus the "delight and darling of the human race." (See also Rome, History of.
title: ROMAN EMPEROR Titus served as a military officer in Germany and BRITAIN in the early years of his career

67 he joined his father (who was not yet emperor) in JUDAEA, where Vespasian was trying to quell a Jewish rebellion. When Vespasian became emperor in A.D. 69 and returned to Rome, Titus remained in Judaea to continue the war against the Jewish rebels. InD A. 70 he captured the city of JERUSALEM, an event recorded by the Jewish histo-'* triumph Roman victory celebration consisting rian JOSEPHUS. Titus returned to Rome in A.D. 71 and received a triumph* in of a procession by the victorious general and honor of his victory over the JEWS. This victory is commemorated in the other notables to the temple of Jupiter Arch of Titus, which still stands in the Roman FORUM. Titus served as CONSUL under his father and was given the power of a TRI-BUNE. He also shared the office of CENSOR with Vespasian. On his father's death in A.D. 79, Titus became emperor. His reign was popular and productive. He maintained good relations with the Roman SENATE and sponsored lavish See GAMES and public spectacles for the people. Titus enriched the city of Rome color plate 2, by building BATHS and completing the construction of the COLOSSEUM

note: Trajan's reign—from A.D. 98 until his death in A.D. 117—was considered a golden age, and he received the title optimus princeps (best of leaders).
title: rajan was one of the most popular and competent rulers of the TRAJAN T Roman Empire. He and the emperors Nerva, HADRIAN, Antoninus Pius, and Marcus AURELIUS are sometimes referred to collectively as the Five Good Emperors. Trajan expanded the territory of the empire, A.D. 53-117 launched an extensive building program in the city of ROME, and extended ROMAN EMPEROR a system of relief for the poor begun by the emperor Nerva

container-title: See map in Visigoths

From their base in North Africa, the Vandals launched devastating attacks on the Mediterranean islands of SICILY, Sardinia, and Corsica. They even invaded Italy, attacking and looting the city of ROME itself in A.D. 455. The powerful Vandal kingdom in North Africa did not last long. In A.D
note: 533 the emperor JUSTINIAN sent an army—under the command of his great general, Belisarius—against the Vandals. The Romans quickly crushed them and destroyed their kingdom. (See also Barbarians; Germans; Migrations, Late Roman; Treaties.
title: This peace ended around A.D. 416, when a combined force of Romans and VISIGOTHS invaded Spain and crushed the Vandals and their allies. Faced with a continuing threat from the Visigoths, the Vandals moved to southern Spain. From there, they crossed the MEDITERRANEAN SEA to North Africa in A.D. 429. By A.D. 435 the Vandals controlled Rome's African provinces of Mauretania and Numidia. They captured the city of CARTHAGE in A.D. 439 and made it the capital of their kingdom
